comments.commentBody: People who microwave fish in the public microwave in the break room at work.  When that guy inexplicably wearing cologne at the gym gets on the treadmill right beside you even though the entire row is empty.  Really big trucks on really big suspension kits with really big tires.  Distracted drivers.  People who don't use turn signals or who forget to turn them off after turning.  Satellite TV door to door salespeople.  False deadlines.  Disrespect for other people's time.  Lateness.  Men trying to tell women what we should do with our bodies.  The stupid new cable menu that doesn't tell me when a program is NEW.

Good! The trend towards restaurant dining may be nice, but conceals one of the most oppressive, racist industries in the country. Why, for example, are all the busboys Hispanic or Asian  and waiters rarely are? The sheer food waste, ostentation, hierarchy, racism, hypocrisy, and labor oppression in fashionable restaurants make the oil industry and garment industry look good by comparison.
He and Donald Trump are litter mates!!
Welcome to the restaurant business!!!!!!  30 years in it and I could share things that most would consider "60 minutes material".  May God forgive them; I and many others are unable to.

This guy looks and sounds a lot like "Len Allison," of "Hubert's" another fake disguised as a "chef." Spent most of his time doing God knows what, rarely cooked (who even knows if he could cook), a smug white con man who ripped a lot of people, rich and poor off.
Bet he writes a book when things cool off.  Something about "mistakes" made by restauranteurs and chefs.  People (sheep) will buy it.
Not watching his show, not going to his restaurants.  Hope he loses the lawsuit.
This man should NOT be living in a 3 million dollar home, but perhaps in a tenement building, much like those his former, and no doubt current, workers can likely afford. Disgusting!

The employees should skip the lawsuit and file complaint with the state employment division regarding these charges. They will investigate. If the claims are true they will go away Zakarian. Then you can sue him.

Unfortunately this abuse of chefs is all too commonplace.  These "celebrities" seem to lose all their integrity and conscience when they become famous. They get rich on the backs of people forced to word 80-90 hours a week for low pay, no breaks, little food.  It is disgraceful.

“This guy made a wonderful piece of chicken. What else matters?”

This statement makes me ill. So what? He's a great chef. That does not give him the right to rip off his cooks and cheat them out the money the earned working for this guy. It's this kind of sense of entitlement that's the problem in this country. People like this think they are above the law or somehow better than others just because they have some talent or ability. At the end of the day he's just a man how cooks food that all ends up in the sewer. Which is where this man's morals are.

I think the city of new York has too much money to spend.  And that money mostly are from Wall Street contributions, I think.  And I don't think those doners will let their money spent for nothing if they are not benefitted in some ways or another.

I though everyone was Special
But if everyone is Special
Then are we not all the same in our Specialness ?

Good Heavens they are Narcissistic beyond all Belief.

What the Baby Boomers who raised this generations of me first
don't realise is that they will be quick and willing to dispose
of dear old Mom and Dad once they can and frankly that is what
dear old Mom and Dad deserve for mis-raising this "Me Only" generation.
I suspect that the problem lies in Hughes' head and not in his arm.

Total nonsense.  If people are too lazy to obtain a single form of government identification, I don't want them voting anyway.  Citizenship should be taken seriously, and if requiring to validate your identity at the polling place with a simple form of ID to prevent fraud is considered a burden, then don't vote.

The Republicans have been big on voter fraud, of which there have been very few documented instances.  So what do they do?  They fight this fictitious problem with legalized election fraud, which places a very heavy GOP thumb on the electoral scales. It's the 21st century successor to the poll tax.
Traditionally those with the least power are the ones with the pitchforks. Maybe we should thank these GOP legislators, for hastening the revolution.

The Republican efforts to suppress voting does not address any legitimate problems facing our country, but it does address a problem facing the Republicans - namely that the majority of voters do not approve of today's GOP. Faced with that reality, Republicans are doing whatever they can to gin up "voting fraud" controversies so that they can limit voting among Democratic leaning populations.

Conservatives have engaged in numerous efforts to try to suppress the Democratic vote, including:

* Caging, which involves sending letters marked “do not forward” to voters, compiling a list of all of the letters that are returned as undelivered, and then challenging the voters on that list when they show up to vote. This approach ignores the fact that the letters might be undelivered because of a mistake in the address list, or because the voter is a college student or in the military, rather than because of a problem with the voter’s qualification to vote. The tea party and other conservatives were found to be planning a major caging effort in Wisconsin for the 2010 election, and caging has been carried out by Republicans in Florida, Ohio, Philadelphia, and other areas in the 2008 and 2004 elections.

* Misinformation – There has been a long string of examples of information targeting Democratic or minority voters with misinformation designed to reduce their voting. Such misinformation includes phone calls announcing that polling places have been moved or fliers informing people of the wrong election day or that people with unpaid traffic tickets will get arrested if they try to vote. Such misinformation targeting Democratic or minority voters was found to be “widespread and deliberate” in the 2006 elections in Virginia, and an organization known as Womens’ Voices has engaged in such misinformation campaign in numerous states such as Michigan, Wisconsin, Ohio, and North Carolina.

* Polling Place Challenges – Polling places in urban areas (which tend to be heavily Democratic), often have too few voting booths, leading to long lines that can discourage voters. These lines are made even longer by deliberate efforts to conservatives to challenge the qualifications of virtually every voter that shows up, with the intent of discouraging both the challenged voter and people who leave the line after staying in it for a few hours.

While Republicans attempt to justify such voter suppression efforts on the grounds that there is purportedly widespread voting fraud occurring, a five-year long investigation by President Bush’s Department of Justice found “virtually no evidence of any organized effort” to fraudulently impact federal elections and other analyses have similarly found no evidence of fraud.

In other words, this latest GOP legislative effort is a "solution" in search of a problem. One has to wonder what it says about today's GOP that so much of their electoral strategy relies on restricting the number of people who get to vote.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

http://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

What are these republicans afraid of? Their own people? Aren't we all Americans first and political party members second? When are they going to start to put the good of the country ahead of the good of their party? I say it's about time! Past time! Do it now! Or we'll find somebody else who wants to do it!

And after they manage to disenfranchise the young, the poor and the elderly, perhaps Republicans will go after women, and then men who aren't landowners. And then they'll have just what they wanted: a return to feudalism. The Republicans' new motto can be: Gone Serfin'

Visit CheeseFoodNation.com

Republicans do not like democracy, so naturally they do their best to suppress it. The laws cited in this article are good examples, though hardly the only. The entire judicial system, for example, is skewed heavily toward those with wealth. See the recent Supreme Court ruling on corporate "personhood" and "freedom of speech" for examples. Our oligarchy is now pushing on the state level those things it could not accomplish yet at a Federal level.

Soon we will not be surfing the net, but serfing life in total.

www.jonjost.wordpress.com
www.cinemaelectronica.wordpress.com
If a state requires a birth certificate to obtain a voter ID, and the state charges a fee for that birth certificate, is that fee then a poll tax?

These voter-id laws are brought to us by the same people who as Southern Democrats used poll taxes and other strategies to keep southern blacks from voting for decades.  It was wrong then and the new voter-id laws are wrong now.

I can't buy a six pack of beer without an ID and I'm 50. I can't get on a plane without an ID. I can't get into most public buildings without an ID. I need an ID to cash a check. I know you folks are paranoid about these things but face facts. There is nothing stopping people from voting illegally in most states.  You stick to your belief that no one ever votes illegally but are happy to trump up charges of voter intimidation or discouragement.  If I were a conspiracy fan I would believe you know there is plenty of illegal voting and like the results.
The Republicans are the Military, need I say more?
